reviewText:
Early Access Review

First time I ever disliked something that bad that im refunding,

The game is really really early and not finished to even be considered early alpha.

I would recommened all fans of the previous games to stay away from it until all the basics are finished.

Everything just feels so bad. no options outside of the launcher.

Some of the noise and models are from Robot arena 2, controls to create the robots are horribly designed for consoles in mind rathar than Pc.

Graphicly feels like a really old game. but i can say the game preforms nicely.

For now i would say to AVOID it, wait it out and see if it fixes most of the problems any Early access game has.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: This review is subject to change as the game gets updated.

Pros:
Good graphics
There's actually a decent selection of AI robots, if you can find them (see the negatives)
Chassis designing is much more flexible
You can now re-position components after they've been placed, and sculpt your chassis around your placed components (if you haven't played RA2, trust me: this is a GODSEND)
Neutral points:
Already a predictable glut of crappy Workshop robots
If you're new to the series then the building and wiring system can take a little getting used to
Cons:
Your choice of parts is hardly any wider than in RA2 (and if you're used to the DSL or Robot Wars mods, as I am, prepare to be sorely disappointed]
Interface is even more confusing than RA2's in places (placing components, setting up controls, selecting robots...)
Controls appear to have been set up for consoles even though the game is a PC-only release
Weight calculation is completely broken. Some parts seem to have ridiculous weight values, the calculations don't always update when they should, the value is completely arbitrary (900 what?) with no indication as to what the weight limit is or whether there even is one... and while building one of my robots I added a component and my bot's weight went DOWN by 500!

This definitely has the potential to surpass RA2, but there are a lot of issues that need ironing out. A lot. But then, that's why they launched in Early Access. I know they had last-minute issues, so I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt. My thumbs-up comes with the expectation that the game's issues will gradually be ironed out over the coming weeks and months. I'll be keeping an eye out and updating this review over time. If these issues don't get fixed, I'll switch to a thumbs-down.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current early access state, I can't recommend the game, simply because it's no better, and probably worse than its predecessor, which, due to it being abandonware is totally free. This sounds like a very harsh thing to say, but unfortunately with steam early access, you never really know if the game will ever come out of it.

Everything about the game is worse really. The physics on the robots are inconsistent, despite the newer engine. It makes fighting the robots feel a bit off. You might hit a guy with a spinning disc and have him not move, then he might drive into a wall and that'll be a much larger 'impact.' I didn't use a wedge, but I'm told the chassis of the robot actually makes no difference, ie, if you make a wedge you can't get under people. I can't confirm that.
The building has been 'simplified' to the point where it trades ease of use for clunkiness. For instance, if you try to add a 'peg board' to the edge of a disc, there's about 15 attach points on one side, and 3 on the other. You have to click change attach point about 15 times, as opposed to just clicking the attach point you want, then on the motor. It's just not streamlined at all, and I can put everything inside eachother.
Next, huge lack of parts. The variety dropped pretty hard in general. There isn't enough weapon motors and the best one isn't strong enough. Moving on, lack of part clarity, none of the motors say how much electricity they draw, as far as I can tell. The armor doesn't necessarilly say how effective it is. Is fibreglass going to give me more or less health than carbon fibre? Something about fire resistance?
On a side note, the music is annoying, the sound effects are low quality and just sound weird, and some are ripped from the old game. The graphics, while not that important, are pretty awful. Somehow even though the textures are higher quality, they are just worse looking than the old game. It's hard to explain. They just look like typical stock unity textures, it looks odd and cartoony. I'm sure you'll get the same feeling when you look at the screenshots. I think it's to do with the lighting.

For me, a robot building/fighting game where the building isn't great and the fighting is plagued by weird physics isn't worth the buy. Wait until full release, then look at the reviews again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Things that have happened while playing the game:
- The menu cursor became stuck going down
- My robot randomly flipped over due to wonky physics
- My robot fell through the floor
- My robot broke immediately at the start of a match
- I moved a robot part under the table in the bot lab and could not click on it anymore
- My opponent's robot cloned itself in multiplayer twice in the same match
- An extra blank robot appeared in multiplayer
- I attempted to join a server that no longer existed, thus softlocking the game because there is no option to close the message
- I pressed the ready button in a server and nothing happened
- The game crashed every other time I tried to play a multiplayer match
- The game crashed my opponent's entire computer
- I contemplated what went wrong in my life that led me to playing this game

This is the Big Rigs of robot building simulators. Don't buy it unless you're a masochist.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a tough one - I wish you could give neutral reviews. But, in its current state, it is very unpolished. There are plenty of  annoying bugs that you will have to work around.

I agree with those saying that you're better off just downloading RA2, BUT I do believe this game will eventually become a worthy sequel. There's just not enough of an improvement over its predecessor to persuade me into giving this a positive review. They are both equally buggy.

If you're a fan of the series, you will most likely find a way to look beyond the bugs and still enjoy it. But, if you aren't a fan, I'd recommend finding and downloading RA2 on gametechmods.com for free, as it is just as enjoyable as this installment of the Robot Arena franchise.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Developers released this game on Early Access with the promise that the game is nearly finished and only the multiplayer needs fixing. It's the reason I bought it, but there are so many issues it's ridicilous.
Things I have noticed from the 20 minutes I have played so far:


Physics are basic at best - RA2 is far superior - this is closer to the Robot Wars games which is not a compliment. Odd noises too, like grinding when just driving along a horizontal floor for no obvious reason.

Terrible cheesy music playing during matches.

When you cause damage, the displayed hit points get in the way of the battle - the font is too big.

When paused, the options option is there but cannot be clicked.

Need to disconnect my Oculus Rift, otherwise it plays the sound through it's speakers and the camera moves with the positional head tracking, which is really weird.

Some menus do not respond to controller input.

You can start a match with just one robot, which is very easy to do as menus respond quick enough that a misplaced double click will make that happen, and then you just have to wait as the match starts and then you instantly win it. Why not just stop one robot battles from happening seeing as it never lets you take control of the robot anyway?

HUD does not scale well with 4K (too small).

In robot creator if I move the camera up it just moves back down to the base of the table automatically for no obvious reason.


I will wait and give the devs a chance before claiming a refund, but I have a terrible feeling this is basically a scam. No developer can possibly honestly state this is nearly finished. It just feels so empty and buggy, they must have known.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stay very clear of this cheap cash in. They seem to be using stock textures in places, I know for a fact one menu background in particular is litterally lifted off of google images without editing. The music is bad, the AI is bad, the announcer has better ♥♥♥♥ to do...

So much potential, squandered on a dev that doesn't seem to care about the combat or building of robots.

They managed to get so very close to how the old games were, but a few critical features are quite simply missing. Rotation snap, for one is a feature you'll be very sorely missing in the builder. The part variety is pitiful. The physics are muted. You can't break off wheels, for some reason. Circular Saws are halariously overpowered for a weapon that is typically useless against everything in real life. Deformation of chassis and frames and armor and anything else you've come to expect from Robot Arena 2 is simply not present.

I tried to build a flipper. They didn't even have a flat panel for me to build it with, so I used two battleaxes. The strongest burst motor in the game can't manage to lift another bot. I tried to get clever with part placement, but my parts disentegrated without warning. I think its clipping protection, but why did they allow me to place it in the first place?

I was really excited for this realease, and given that its an indie team I was willing to forgive a lot. But the shear amount of inept design and slapdash... everything leads me to believe that this was a project done in a few months in someone's spare time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A sad day for RA fans.
Its obvious this game was made to cash in on the fact that Battlebots is now back on air.

The game is low quality and feels rushed. There are gameplay problems that werent existent in RA2. The stock bots are built in such a way they clip through there own components during firing. Wacking a wall sends your bot flying.
Options within pause menu does nothing.
In MP I was unable to start a session after 20 minutes. People join and dont ready up, you create a lobby for 2 players and 3 join. Theres no option to kick anyone, no servers appeared for me but people did join mine. The controls are setup for console for some reason. Icons are terrible quality and the whole game is under 400mb. Component selection is lacking. Really dissapointed by this, had very high hopes but this game exists only to take advantage of a re-emerging community.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros: It's a new Robot Arena.
Cons: It's not as good as Robot Arena 2 at the moment.

Building a bot: Parts are intangible, this makes construction easy but unrealistic.  Painting the bot is nearly impossible unless you use a cube shape for the body.  There are tons of custom button assignments for the controller giving you complete control over the weapons and attachments.

Fighting the bot: The AI bots need a lot of work, they aren't aggressive enough.  The bodies don't seem to show damage very well.  The matches are over way too quickly, usually less than 30 seconds.

Overall: The game has great potential and receptive developers, I can't wait to see how it progresses.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most of the problems in this game have been caused by the fact you cant have normal components in contact with the ground and the fact the game picks up random signals from controllers which seemed to be the cause of every other glitch or bug i found.

The paint shop works fine, granted its a bit confusing but once you get used to it and figure out how it works you end up having alot more flexability than in RA2 which i find better.

The bot building its way more complicated but you can still build very effective and powerfull robots, once you take the time to learn how. I even built a micro robot which won an entire tournament effortlessly. And my ripsaw robot from RA2(Which i needed mods to be able to build) i managed to build in this with nothing but the tools provided and still manages to defeat all opponents in less than 20 seconds.

My only problem with this game is that you do need to build robots to have nothing but wheel compoments in contact with the ground also the normal motors in the game are extremely slow in comparison to RA2, but thats fine because this games still in development.

Developers want your feedback on what YOU want in this game you mightaswell give them the chance to give you the game you always dreamed of. Sure its not right now but im sure it will be if you give it a chance, i know i will be doing everything i can to help the developers make this game what it should be and i hope plenty others will too.
voteText: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to write a big review on this but for now- don't waste your money. Seriously.

UI is old and looks outdated.
No weight classes.
Scale of size is terrible.
You can only move at one speed.
You have to very precisely move components into place as there is no snap to grid function.
You can not edit a bot once you've uploaded it to the Steam workshop.
Components can go outside the chassis.
Components can be overlapped with ease.
You don't need a control board to wire up a robot.
The online functionality is broken. The host always wins.
You can move before the game starts when in online play.
Servos and burst motors stay in the air when moving the start/finish and therefore cannot be judged easily.
Parts can go through the robot during gameplay. (I was able to break the burst motor basically)
You can't make a two wheel robot properly.
The chassis can be distorted to be put through itself.
Havok" explosions have happened on multiplayer.
Camera constantly moves down in the bot editor at times.
Camera angles have to be changed via mouse.
The skinning system is terrible and needs to be reworked.
Train runs robots over

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the time I'm writing this, it had been released for a couple of hours and I have played it for just under two hours.  And as much as I love the idea of the reboot, it feels dated.  And sluggish.  I just wish there'd be faster motors, real life robots such as England's own Warhead or America's Bite Force, and a way to make your own drive train, so you can legitimately make either a push bot, or a faster spinner for your robot, or a drum weapon.  On top of that, the motors only seem to point forward when you first put them in, making it a real hassle to make the robot move forward properly.  A majority of the robots in the game as well just feel haphazardly put together as well, with blade spam all over them.

Pros:
+ It's a nostalgic return to the Robot Arena series.
+ Arcade like, and super quick loading times
+ Axe like weapons feel like they can deliver a punch.

Cons: (Oh boy this is going to be long)
- Customisation feels rather limited.
- No faster motors or powerul motors.
- Spinners feel like and look like a wet noodle.
- No real life robots in the game right now.
- Preset chassis are small and unvaried.
- One graphic on a robot replaces all graphics on all robots.  Not sure if a glitch or really poor design.
- Making low profile robots makes awful clanking noises.
- Graphics on some styles of robot stretches and makes it look ugly as sin.

What I would like to see in the future of this game:
*FASTER MOTORS: I want to be able to create a hard hitting spinner bot or a robot that uses a drum weapon and still keep its ability to ram into opponents quickly.
*REAL ROBOTS: I wish to see robots old and new in the game.  Whether or not this'll happen is something completely different.
*ACTUAL STATS ON ROBOT PARTS: One thing I have noticed is there's a lack of info on parts.  If this gets updated I'd be fairly okay with it.
*A DRIVE TRAIN SYSTEM: Having a steering column is nice and all but I would love to make a robot that can steer on a six pence without having to fiddle with motor positioning.  On top of that, I'd love to see a choice between either belt or chain drive, for those who wish to make a robot on a tank drive steering system.
*DIFFERENT FORMS OF LOCOMOTION: Wheels are cool, but tank tracks, Walking legs, or even a Half track system would be excellent.
*WEIGHT CATEGORIES: Right now, all the robot seem to be in the same kind of weight category, which is quite misleading.
*MORE ARENAS!!!: Can't stress that enough right now.  Being in a real arena would be fantastic, such as the old Robot Wars arena or the new Battlebots Battle box.

Overall, this feels really outdated and in need of some more work, if I'm brutally honest Octopus Tree.  It doesn't feel polished, and it feels a little rushed on top of that.  Unless this game gets a really big update and pretty much changes the game into a much more customisable game that actually feels like I'm making a robot, then I'd say avoid this for now.

A really disappointing start for such a promising game!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lower your expectations if you're buying into this - what they originally described as a 'feature complete game with a few last minute issues we'll fix while in a few weeks of early access' is buggy, barebones and in places fundamentally broken. The devs have taken a step back to their credit and conceded they're not as close to a full game as they thought they were, have shown to be passionate at every step and are willing to accept feedback - the question becomes if you're willing to be an early alpha tester.

It's a lawless wasteland with no weight classes and where anything can be mounted anywhere - through other components, or even several feet away from the actual robot. Every chassis has box collision - if it's a wedge design or has a portion cut out to herd other robots (i.e a 'dustpan' design), it doesn't matter. The fact that chassis wedges do not work to any degree is an absurd oversight.

I can still however draw fun from the game. The chassis builder is powerful (when you disregard the above issues) and they have the right ideas about modernising the build system. It’s just undercooked, with glaring faults and omissions. When you get the proper experience with the wonky physics it can be satisfying; big, heavy bots like EMERGENCY clones are king, able to run down everything in it's path.

What I can get from the game personally doesn't mean this game is not poor in it's current state - but all of Gametechmods and the Robot Arena community are looking ahead to Robot Arena 3's eventual rise to glory.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I probably log ged thousands of hours in RA2, and I loved it.  I was very very worried this one would wind up being a sad rehash or a 15 dollar clone of RA2 but I was pleasently surprised.  Yes, this is an unfinished version with alot of problems, but they're still working on it and once the bugs are ironed out I can seen this being a worthy follow-up
Just the fact that now I can move components, even when their linked, makes design so much easier.  Right now positioning the components are fiddly, I'm hoping they'll tightne this up a bit.  The new components are great, chainsaws were saddly missing form the original, and even though Chainsaws are useless in real robotic combat, getting the option to use one is great.  Also, the inclusion of barrel components is a good addition.  When RA2 was released barrel spinners were faily new but now that they're established in the sport throwing them in is great.
Again, this is pre-release, so threre are alot of problems.  Right now the program is pretty unstable, and I can see a hundred small fixes that would make this game alot better.  Hopefully the developers won't let these problems slide, because I'm excited for the future of this game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Bot Lab is more interesting. It's more complicated, but it gives room for a bigger variety when it comes to robots. At least for the chassis. The size of the parts is... not a good balance. The motors I find too small and the batteries too big. There isn't enough of a variety of parts. Yet. The placement of the parts start below the bottom of the chassis instead of at the bottom of the chassis like RA2 does. The physics aren't the best, and it's pretty slow. The robots are particularly slow. There needs to be some motors that have something like a chain drive/belt drive with it instead of only direct drive. This is probably a common complaint, but the parts don't have to be inside the chassis or attached to the chassis at all for some reason. The game overall has a lot of potential. The Lab has some great ideas particularly, but this is a very unpolished and unfinished game. I'm hoping for it to improve soon. As of now, to my dismay, I can't recommend the game to anyone though

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Whilst I love how good the chassis customisation is, and the Bot Lab is on the whole very impressive when it comes to user-friendliness, there are a few too many problems that I have already encountered:

- The combat runs very slowly, even on minimum settings on my computer (which hasn't any trouble running games such as Skyrim), frequently dropping to 4 fps, which makes one of the main two game features unplayable.
- It is even harder than in RA 2 to line up components with each other, and also the number of connection points seems limited, which is a pain when trying to build bots (what I spent most of my time doing)
- The game crashed multiple times in the Bot Lab
- The paint system doesn't really work on the 'sides' in the lab (a minor thing, I know)
- All my robots have 37 wins and 6 defeats...

I haven't tried the online multiplayer yet, as I don't think I would enjoy it due to the framerate, but I do have hopes for this and hope for the solving of the problems in the game. However, while I want to, I can't viably recommend this game to anyone at the moment.

Please solve these problems - I really want to give this game a positive review!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to write a good review because this game is fun. It's EARLY ACCESS! All those negative reviews after half an hour of gameplay shouldn't exist. It's not the prettiest game, the soundtrack is rough, but there are good things too!

What to expect.
1. Building is fun, the chassis doesn't always appear as smooth as it should, seems to not be mirrored when you build a bot with sloping sides.
2. Lots of components. You can pretty much build whatever you want. You'll see some CRAZY designs in the arenas. This is the reason we all play this game anyway.
3. The AI aren't horrible. It's early access so I played one game where the bots just flipped themselves on the weird map and timed out but in a simple map they seem to fight decently. In a tournament you'll face such variety that one type of bot won't win everything with ease.
4. Painting the bots needs a lot of work. Textures are all messed up.

Overall I recommend this game. You'll have fun if you can get past it being a little buggy. The worst thing I've experienced was getting thrown accross the arena when an opponent's weapon moved back to it's starting position and I was in the way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR -Not great, but buy it anyway, and hopefully the devs will get the budget they need to make Robot Arena 4 the way this game should have been made in the first place.

---

So, the devs only started showing progress on the game about 5 months ago. That is not nearly enough time to put together a solid game of any kind. This game reflects that lack of time and budget they were given.

The improvements to the bot lab are awesome. There is so much more freedom in how a robot can be built now. But that is hampered by the lack of any snap points for component placement or rotation. It's impossible to get any component pointed exactly the same way as any other component, or at the same height. Just adding some snap points would make the bot lab nearly perfect.

Unfortunately from there, things get bad. Combat is much more like Robot Arena 1 than anything: slow boxes covered in components driving straight at each other. Even though you can flip other robots over, no matter how you build your chassis shape you cannot simply drive under other robots. You mearly bump into them until some physics instability allows you to accidentally end up underneith. Collisions are super simple. Most of the time chassis and components wont be anywhere near each other when their hit boxes collide. No matter how a match is lost, it classifies every losing robot as immobilized". Sometimes already counted out robots will get counted out a second time. I can barely hear the "announcer" despite volumes being turned up all the way.

The menus for some reason are designed as if I'm using an Xbox controller when I only have keyboard and mouse hooked up. It was quite confusing when it said "Press (A) to continue". Some of the menus apparently scroll
date: although there are no indications of this except for some images being slightly cut off. Click and drag is the way to scroll these menus for some reason.\n\nTextures look ok
hoursPlayed: so no real complaints on the graphics side of things. There are more parts available than in stock Robot Arena 2
voteText: so that is an improvement. Background music is uninspiring stock instrumental stuff.\n\nIf I had to play this on a tablet or something
votesHelpful: but being released through Steam for PC users
votesTotal: this game is currently a 3/10. It should be way better
votesFunny: but for some reason the studio decided to rush it out in only 5-8 months to test the market. Hopefully they both decide to make a Robot Arena 4
commentsCount: and go all out in making it the most realistic simulation of robot combat ever made like we want instead of the arcadey little toy they gave us."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ive spent a bit of time playing round and fighting now and think i have seen enough to make a review. Firstly it does have the odd bug but then again thats why its advertised as an earlly access game. The bot creation can be a bit of a pain as the components start under the chassis and you have to adjust them and the rotation isnt as smooth as ra2. I encountered a glitch while testing the robot where it tends to fly or topple over but found adding weights to the robot stabilised it. Also if i could change something else it would be the ai controlled robots. In a career match they spend their time attacking already beat robots to rack up scores making it very hard to beat them.

Anyway i gave this game a thumbs up because despite all the bad reviews and bugs its still easy to have fun. The creations have more possibilities and its easier to connect things for example the wheels. The graphics still dont seem as what promised but to be honest why are graphics so important? Its fun and passes time nicely. I cant wait to see the finished product.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game, despite the popular opinion of others playing it, is NOT that bad.
As it is an early release and the devs are listening to us, we need to look at it in a positive way. There were clearly going to be bugs this early.
I have 12 or so hours clocked and i have witnessed bugs on single multiplayer and the menus but the game is certainly playable.

The new layers system for the body of the robot is a really good idea and a massive leap from RA2. There are problems here- as in most places, however. The first is very annoying when you try and re-edit a robot after a match. It seems that the camera coding breaks as it moves itself to the top with nothing you can do about it:( Also sometimes the position of the dot for the body is nowhere near where the mouse cursor is, which can make finding the correct square harder. The paint job thing at the moment is fairly poor because unless it is a flat side, the paint will look wrong - had to stick to plain colours...
Another thing is that none of the motors seem to be powerful enough to make a fast robot or spinner (which btw the game is still sadly aimed at- you firestorm/chaos 2 lovers will be saddened by the same scoring system and the fact that chassis don't seem to be able to get underneath anything.) you have to use 2 of the bestest fastest motors - the z-tek HP - if you want to move quickly and cheating with parts inside of each other is always necessary. You guys need to add the mass classes back in and have a non-competitive over-weight class just for the lols.
In the way of multiplayer, as far as i have heard you can only do 2 player atm? if so then obvs thats something to fix but i have only tried 2 player. It seems you can only use arenas such as soccer pitch and specific robots as well? it is a bit dodgy but i got a few games in while i could.
A problem as with this and the previous robot arena is the fact that if you jnust cover yourself in spikes and ram the oponent you will never lose as you get constant points and they die very quickly. Personally i love flippers and theres very little ways of winning, except immobilising - which is IMPOSSIBLE on the spinner bot ai because it spins back, making that bot easily the best?
The bot cam is a good idea and on my robots have worked a charm and look good if you position well! So actually well done on that!XD However, you guys need to add and orbit view that follows your bot so that you can choose exacly where youre looking as i feel none of them look in the right place atm.
I completed the career tournaments losing 10 and winning 11 (when i found lots of spikes work) and there is now no way of me playing career again? it does not reset or keep score and when you win or lose a tournament it doesn't tell you.
I could be wrong on this but i'm pretty sure theres something slightly off with the armour, im not sure what it is but im sure it's there where steel is just so weak.
On many of the maps there is a pit/somewhere to fall off - but it does not count as losing in many places in you fall in, which clearly is an issue, you can also lose as a bot that got pitted is driving around in there with more points than you.
The damage also looks very strange, it seems to just lower the top layer down a bit and nothing else...
I love the idea of being able to add your bot to the steam workshop, although im not sure whether my internet isn't loading it very well or what and im not sure if my bot got uploaded as well..XD
I tried using a controller to play as it looked like it was set up for it, but apparently not... also in the menus you quite often get a bug where it keeps scrolling down, it doesn't select anything, it is just annoying.

At the moment you have a good starting point, and i wouldn't say it was 90% ready tbh. The original selection of parts is never enormous - i hope modders share my enthusiasm and make parts and things when the game reaching full release. There is actually so much potential in the game and it is very close to reaching it. Despite everything i have said, i like the game and will play it over RA2 in the hope that bugs are flipped out the arena Chaos 2 style and glitches are destroyed Razor style... Keep the update coming and we'll have a great game eventually. I'm going to vote recommend in the hope that things i mentioned are eventually polished off.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

First of all, before I get into my personal opinions on this game I just want to remind the people who gave this a negative vote that this game is in early access. This game is not finished and it won't be finished for a while. So for those of you who gave a totally biased review complaining about the lack of features and bugs, all I can say to you is before you publish a review knocking a game, give the developers time to work on and fix the game. Now, moving onto my opinions about the game...

In it's current state the game is alright, not the greatest, but not the worst either. The game has the potential to become better than it's predecessor. Here's the pros and cons of the game:

Pros:

*Graphics are better, more realistic.
*New Bot Lab adds more customization.
*Fighting is a lot smoother than in RA2
*More Parts to work with.

Cons:

*No max weight
*No weight classes
*When damaged in a tournament match if you win, you automaticly move onto the next round without having to repair your components.
*Paintshop doesn't work right now.
*UI is unpolished

Final thoughts:

I highly recommend Robot Arena 3 regardless of the glitches but I don't recommend it while it's in early access. Wait for the game to actually be finished before you buy it or if you do want to buy it in it's current state, be prepared for lack of features, unpolished UI, and glitches.

BUT it is easy to see that they are moving in the right direction, and if they continue to improve the gameplay to the point of it matching RA2, and keep all the new features they have/will add to this game, it is definitely worth buying.

Early Access Review

I'm a long-time RA2 fan, and chomping at the bit to dig into RA3.

Currently, the game is lacking polish and there are a number of game-breaking issues, but it has a lot of potential and makes some immediate improvements on RA2's bot lab. I'm hopeful that on-going development will address most of the issues and we'll have a proper successor to RA3.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is rather unfinished but shows promise, however there are a few MAJOR problems that prevent it from living up to it's potential, which should hopefully be fixed once out of Early Access.

WHAT IS GOOD:
- The new chassis mechanic is fantastic.
- The ability to place components inside of each other makes for excellent IRL building
- The game is a LOT more stable than RA2
- The combat system is very fun
- The Arenas are really creative, and I especially like the new disco arena.
- Developers are actually taking feedback on what is wrong with the game too, which sadly
doesn't always happen with indie titles

WHAT IS NEEDED:
- The UI is a complete disaster... Although that can be easily fixed by modding when mod
support comes around.
- Being able to fire your weapons in the bot lab.
- Burst motors moving as you change their start and end points is going to be a good idea, and
would help when trying to build flippers.
- Snap Rotation, and component raising.
- Rotation speed up
- Motor speeds need to be tweaked, as they are too slow.

As is I cannot decide weather or not to reccomend this title unless you are willing to take a risk. Yes it is broken but It's thumbs up because it is still fun.

Grade: No grade for Early Access titles
